text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's
busiest music nerd and we're gonna do a
quick review of the new Black Sabbath
album thirteen Black Sabbath from the UK
Godfather's of doom metal legendary
metal band a band that I constantly
recommend if if people ever say to me
Anthony how do you get into metal listen
too early Black Sabbath albums not only
can you just not go wrong with any of
the band's initial LPS the self-titled
paranoid master of reality the hits go
on and and what's cool is that great
records from this band continued to come
out even after they switched lead
singers from Ozzy Osbourne to Ronnie
James Dio but now with 13 we're dealing
with with basically the first Black
Sabbath album to have Ozzy on it since
like the 70s and we're working with an
original lineup on this LP - except for
drummer Bill Ward unfortunately actually
Brad Wilk of Rage Against the Machine
have replaced him on this LP for all the
studio sessions and as much as I love
Rage Against the Machine and I know Brad
Wilk to be an incredibly capable drummer
still just all the changes all the time
just all the weak solo projects it all
just maybe very skeptical to listen to
this album the the the Frank Zappa and
the mothers of invention album title
were only in it for the money comes to
mind when I gave this album a listen I I
did get the sense that Ozzy Iommi and
geezer are just really not messing
around for one osses vocals on the rest
of this album outside of the goddess
dead track are way more on point and at
times sounding pretty sinister even
though Ozzy hasn't always been with
Sabbath he's never really stopped
singing throughout his career so it's
not like he needs to kind of get back in
gear with that or anything there have
been critics of how Ozzy has performed
in the live setting as of late but in
regards to putting together the
performances for this album I mean
Ozzy's vocals came out good maybe he's
not coming
as extreme as he used to but for sure I
mean he sounds captivating he sounds
like his signature self and not to
mention the really awesome harmonica
solo on the track damaged soul it really
feels like Black Sabbath is taking us
back to the old days with Ozzy doing
that and Tony Iommi's riffs they're
heavy they're slow they're just dark but
there is a little bit of a lack of
momentum to them a lack of groove to
them there isn't this vast chilling
creepy openness to them that made a lot
of the band's previous work just so
eerie and for the most part the reason
that is is because of the the very bad
production choices that happen on this
album there's just way too much volume
and compression on this LP I just don't
know what was up with Rick Rubin
producing this album Black Sabbath they
come from a time when there wasn't an
extreme amount of compression being laid
upon every single track in modern metal
music because let's face it metal music
more than most genres abuses distortion
and compression because everybody's got
to be the hardest the heaviest and the
loudest and I feel like Black Sabbath
felt some kind of pressure to compete in
that lane unfortunately instead of just
kind of letting the natural and
fantastic tones and sounds of the
guitars and bass shine through and
that's another thing the extreme use of
compression on this album really buries
geezers bass to the point where you
can't even really make out what it's
doing half of the time I know that there
are modern records that make use of this
that do sound good and you know I I'm
not taking anything away from them but
Black Sabbath they play in a style that
sounds better when it's not choked off
with compression as good as some of the
songwriting is on this album I can't
help but feel like the sound could be so
much better
I actually think even Brad Wilkes drums
suffer a little bit at the hands of just
Tony Iommi's guitars being fattened and
turned up all the way and in terms of
just really structuring these songs Ozzy
and company are not screwing around
either they're not writing really short
tracks with
cutting out and just and leaving and
turning in the other direction I mean
they have delivered over ten songs here
that a lot of them land in the seven
eight-minute mark
Black Sabbath is coming off pretty
ambitious with their songwriting and
their padding these songs out justifying
these lengths with multiple parts
moments where things speed up really
awesome solos to be completely honest
the solos are really the most riveting
thing on this album aside from some of
the vocal performances and the harmonica
the solos are really where Tony lets
loose and and and makes this record feel
kind of wild and free which is really
necessary given how much the compression
and and everything else kind of locks it
flattens it and makes it feel slightly
lifeless no way this thing is going to
be one of my favorite Black Sabbath
records ever but I actually am am pretty
surprised that it did not come out as
horrible as I thought it would I
actually did come out of this thing
liking a lot of the tracks I just wish
the sound was better you know even
though I think the songs are good and I
think technically the performances were
all on point I I just think the sound
should have been reconsidered you know I
mean if Black Sabbath was gonna go all
the way back and try to really recapture
the magic of their older stuff by
writing songs in a similar vein and
believe me there are even riffs on this
album that sounds similar to riffs from
their first four records if they were
gonna go back and try to recapture that
magic playing wise technically they
could have at least attempted to
recapture that as well through just the
sound of the instrumentation the sound
of the production that's pretty much my
take on this LP if you've given it a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana Black Sabbath
[Music]
you
